sen.j: 朽木氏（くつきし）は日本の氏族の一つ。
sen.e: Kutsuki clan was one of the clans of Japan.
Kutsuki clan was one of the clans of Japan.
Kutsuki clan was one of the clans of Japan.

sen.j: 近江源氏佐々木氏の分流である高島氏の有力庶家。
sen.e: It was an influential branch family of the Takashima clan, which was the branch of the Omi Genji Sasaki clan.
It was an influential branch family of the Takashima clan, which was a branch of the Omi Genji Sasaki clan.
sen.cmt: the branchを a branchに変更。
sen.e: It was an influential branch family of the Takashima clan, which was a branch of the Omi Genji Sasaki clan.

sen.j: 高島郡の中でも、安曇川上流域（高島郡北部）である朽木谷を領した。
sen.e: Kutsuki clan controlled Kutsuki-dani, the upper reaches of Ado-gawa River (the northern part of Takashima County) in Takashima County.
Kutsuki clan controlled Kutsuki-dani, which lay in the upper reaches of Ado-gawa River (the northern part of Takashima County) in Takashima County.
sen.cmt: the upper reachesの前にwhich lay in を挿入
sen.e: Kutsuki clan controlled Kutsuki-dani, which lay in the upper reaches of Ado-gawa River (the northern part of Takashima County) in Takashima County.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代から江戸時代にかけて活動した。
sen.e: The Kutsuki clan was active from the Kamakura period to the Edo period.
The Kutsuki clan was active from the Kamakura period to the Edo period.
The Kutsuki clan was active from the Kamakura period to the Edo period.
Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 佐々木信綱の子高島高信の次男朽木頼綱を祖とする。
sen.e: The ancestor of the Kutsuki clan was Yoritsuna KUTSUKI, the second son of Takanobu TAKASHIMA, the son of Nobutsuna SASAKI.
The ancestor of the Kutsuki clan was Yoritsuna KUTSUKI, the second son of Takanobu TAKASHIMA, the son of Nobutsuna SASAKI.
The ancestor of the Kutsuki clan was Yoritsuna KUTSUKI, the second son of Takanobu TAKASHIMA, the son of Nobutsuna SASAKI.

sen.j: 近江国朽木庄を領した為朽木氏を称した（宗家である高島氏は高信の長子である泰信が継承した）。
sen.e: The clan adopted the name Kutsuki because it controlled Kutsuki sho in Omi Province (the Takashima clan, the head family, was succeeded by Yasunobu, the eldest son of Takanobu).
The clan adopted the name Kutsuki because it controlled Kutsuki sho in Omi Province (the Takashima clan, the head family, was succeeded by Yasunobu, the eldest son of Takanobu).
The clan adopted the name Kutsuki because it controlled Kutsuki sho in Omi Province (the Takashima clan, the head family, was succeeded by Yasunobu, the eldest son of Takanobu).

sen.j: 庶家には横山氏・田中氏がある。
sen.e: Branch families included the Yokoyama clan and Tanaka clan.
Yokoyama and Tanaka clans were its branch families.
Yokoyama and Tanaka clans were its branch families.

sen.j: 朽木経氏は、桓武平氏の嫡流池氏の池顕盛の猶子となり池氏の所領も相続した。
sen.e: Tsuneuji KUTSUKI became the heir of Akimori IKE from the Ike clan, the main branch of Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan), and inherited the territory of the Ike clan.
Tsuneuji KUTSUKI became the heir of Akimori IKE from the Ike clan, the main branch of Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan), and inherited the territory of the Ike clan.
Tsuneuji KUTSUKI became the heir of Akimori IKE from the Ike clan, the main branch of Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan), and inherited the territory of the Ike clan.

sen.j: 室町時代には足利将軍家に仕え、室町幕府の側近として仕えた。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, the Kutsuki clan served for the Ashikaga Shogunal family as a close retainer of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
In the Muromachi period, the Kutsuki clan served for the Ashikaga Shogunate family as a close retainer of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
In the Muromachi period, the Kutsuki clan served for the Ashikaga Shogunate family as a close retainer of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 足利将軍の没落後、朽木元綱は織田信長、豊臣秀吉に仕え領土を保全し大名として家名を保った。
sen.e: After the fall of Ashikaga Shogun, Mototsuna KUTSUKI served for Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and possessed territories, maintaining the family name as a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord).
After the fall of Ashikaga Shogun, Mototsuna KUTSUKI served for Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, kept possessing his territory, and maintained the family name as a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord).
After the fall of Ashikaga Shogun, Mototsuna KUTSUKI served for Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, kept possessing his territory, and maintained the family name as a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord).

sen.j: 関ヶ原の戦いにおいては当初西軍についたが東軍に内通し、そのため江戸幕府成立後も大名として存続を許された。
sen.e: In the Battle of Sekigahara, the Kutsuki clan originally supported Western Camp but then held secret communication with Eastern Camp, and therefore was permitted to survive as the daimyo even after the establishment of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

In the Battle of Sekigahara, the Kutsuki clan originally supported Western Camp but later engaged in secret communication with Eastern Camp, so that the clan was permitted to survive as a daimyo even after the establishment of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: held in をengaged in 変更。その他表現の見直し。
sen.e: In the Battle of Sekigahara, the Kutsuki clan originally supported Western Camp but later engaged in secret communication with Eastern Camp, so that the clan was permitted to survive as a daimyo even after the establishment of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 元綱の死後、領土は子孫に分割されたため嫡流は交代寄合の旗本として存続した。
sen.e: Since the territory was divided for the descendants after the death of Mototsuna, the branch family survived as hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) of kotaiyoriai (alternate yoriai, a family status of samurai warriors in the Edo period).

Since the territory was divided into pieces for the descendants after the death of Mototsuna, the main branch family survived as hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) of kotaiyoriai (alternate yoriai, a family status of samurai warriors in the Edo period).
sen.cmt: dividedの後ろにinto piecesを追加。branch familyの前にmainを挿入しthe main branch familyとした。
sen.e: Since the territory was divided into pieces for the descendants after the death of Mototsuna, the main branch family survived as hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) of kotaiyoriai (alternate yoriai, a family status of samurai warriors in the Edo period).

sen.j: また、元綱の三男・朽木稙綱 (土浦藩主)は幕臣として若年寄に就任した。
sen.e: In addition, Tanetsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain), the third son of Mototsuna, was appointed as wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu) as a Shogun's retainer.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, Tanetsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain), the third son of Mototsuna, was appointed as wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu) as a Shogun's retainer.
In addition, Tanetsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain), the third son of Mototsuna, was appointed as wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu) as a Shogun's retainer.

sen.j: その功で下野国鹿沼藩の大名となっている（その後常陸国土浦藩を経て、丹波国福知山藩で明治維新まで存続する）。
sen.e: Thanks to his achievements, the Kutsuki clan became a daimyo in the Kanuma Domain in Shimotsuke Province (after that, it survived in the Tsuchiura Domain in Hitachi Province, and then in the Fukuchiyama Domain in Tanba Province until Meiji Restoration).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thanks to his achievements there, Tanetsuna became a daimyo in the Kanuma Domain in Shimotsuke Province (after that, the Tanetsuna family line moved to the Tsuchiura Domain in Hitachi Province, and lastly moved and stayed in the Fukuchiyama Domain in Tanba Province until the Meiji Restoration).
sen.cmt: 大名になったのは稙綱なのでそれを明示、Meiji Restoration に定冠詞the を付与、その他表現の見直し。
sen.e: Thanks to his achievements there, Tanetsuna became a daimyo in the Kanuma Domain in Shimotsuke Province (after that, the Tanetsuna family line moved to the Tsuchiura Domain in Hitachi Province, and lastly moved and stayed in the Fukuchiyama Domain in Tanba Province until the Meiji Restoration).

sen.j: また宣綱の子の一人高通が外家の号京極を名乗り、丹後峰山藩の大名となっている。
sen.e: Takamichi, a son of Nobutsuna, identified himself as Kyogoku, the name of his maternal family, and became the daimyo in the Tango Mineyama Domain.
Takamichi, a son of Nobutsuna, identified himself as Kyogoku, the name of his maternal family, and became the daimyo of the Tango Mineyama Domain.
sen.cmt: the daimyo in を the daimyo of に変更
sen.e: Takamichi, a son of Nobutsuna, identified himself as Kyogoku, the name of his maternal family, and became the daimyo of the Tango Mineyama Domain.
